New Records: The Dodgers gave the nod to veteran righty Jack Flaherty, but he was pulled in the second inning as Dave Roberts shuffled between his bullpen again, eventually ending with star starter Walker Buehler closing it out.
The Dodgers won their eighth World Series and first since 2020, while the Yankees' drought since 2009 persisted.

The Yankees are the only MLB team to: blow a 5+ run lead, allow 5+ unearned runs, commit 3+ errors, commit catcher's interference, commit a balk, all in the same game, regular season or postseason (since earned runs became an official stat in both leagues in 1913).
Key Match Events: Aaron Judge and Jazz Chisholm Jr. hit back-to-back homers in the bottom of the first for a 3-0 lead, which increased to 4-0 in the second and 5-0 in the third.
A sloppy defensive showing by New York in the fifth inning gave the Dodgers their first scores, eventually tying the game.
A sacrifice fly from Giancarlo Stanton in the bottom of the sixth saw Juan Soto reach home for New York to take a 6-5 lead, but L.A. came back in the top of the eighth and didn't look back.
Catcher's interference call leads to Mookie Betts' go-ahead sac fly for Dodgers.
Walker Buehler, the team's starting pitcher from Game 3, came on in relief in the ninth inning and secured a 7-6 win over the New York Yankees in Game 5 of the Fall Classic.
Blake Treinen escapes jam to put Dodgers three outs away from title.

Freddie Freeman hit the first walk-off grand slam in World Series history in Game 1, and homered in the first four games of the series, including two-run homers in the first inning of both Game 3 and Game 4.

The Dodgers erased a 5-0 deficit to capture their second championship in five seasons, and first full-season title since 1988. It was the largest comeback in a World Series clinching game in Major League Baseball history.
Pre-Game Insights: Dave Roberts had a warm exchange with former Yankees and Dodgers manager Joe Torre, via NBC Los Angeles' Michael Duarte, as Ken Griffey Jr. and Raul Ibanez looked on.
Alex Vesia shared a message for fans ahead of Game 5.
The Yankees' World Series hopes have slightly increased, and so too have their ticket prices, after the team's 11-4 win over the Los Angeles Dodgers in Game 4 on Tuesday to avoid a sweep.
Post-Match Reflections: Aaron Boone reacted to the loss against the Dodgers in the World Series, saying he's 'heartbroken.'
Alex Rodriguez got to see how Game 5 unfolded live and called New York's loss 'one of the greatest meltdowns' he's seen in 40 years during FOX's broadcast of the game.
Daniel Hudson, 37, announced his retirement from the sport following Los Angeles' triumph.
Freddie Freeman discussed his tough year on and off the field and how it all was worth it after winning the World Series.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The LAPD is reminding fans to celebrate the occasion responsibly.
The 'D' in the Hollywood sign was lit up blue to honor the Los Angeles Dodgers' World Series win on Wednesday night.
The Dodgers fans took to the streets following World Series win.
The Dodgers' World Series parade and stadium celebration set for Friday, November 1.
The Dodgers announce plans for World Series parade.
The Dodgers' final out shown on scoreboard at Los Angeles Kings game.
Juan Soto is slated to hit free agency, and with the loss, will the star want to run it back in the Bronx or look elsewhere?
Shohei Ohtani is a World Series champion, and the first member of the 50-50 club to win a championship.
The Yankees redistributed ejected fans' tickets to a pediatric cancer patient and his family, the Yankees said ahead of the game.
Others: The Dodgers' Jack Flaherty started Game 5, and Gerrit Cole started for the Yankees.
The Yankees' Anthony Volpe doubles, scores on Alex Verdugo's RBI single.
Gerrit Cole continues hot start in second inning, retiring Dodgers in order.
Gerrit Cole retires Dodgers stars in order to open first inning.
Babyface performs national anthem ahead of Game 5.
The Yankees fans who ripped the ball out of Mookie Betts' glove banned from Game 5.
The Dodgers tweak lineup heading into Game 5.
The Yankees' starting lineup unchanged for Game 5.
